1.title: Do Exactly What's Asked
1.content: If your friend asks you to make a peanut butter sandwich, don't add jelly unless they ask for it. Follow instructions exactly without adding your own ideas.

2.title: Only Use Information You're Given
2.content: If you're baking cookies and the recipe doesn't say how much sugar to use, stop and ask. Don't guess or make up an amount.

3.title: Protect People's Privacy
3.content: Treat everyone's personal information like a secret diary. Don't look at it, don't share it, and definitely don't write it down where others can see it.

4.title: Use Settings Files, Not Hardcoded Numbers
4.content: Instead of writing "use 10 apples" in your recipe, write "use [number] apples" and keep the number 10 in a separate note. This way you can easily change to 12 apples later.

5.title: Keep Good Records
5.content:
Like keeping a science lab notebook - write down what you did, when you did it, and what happened. Use the format your teacher asks for, and don't add extra stuff they didn't request.
Where we keep these records:
- Action receipts ‚Üí Like a shopping list that only gets longer (JSONL files)
- Error and performance notes ‚Üí Like an organized notebook (SQLite database)
- Everything stays private ‚Üí Never leaves your computer without permission

6.title: Never Break Things During Updates
6.content:
When updating a video game, you should still be able to play while it updates. If the update causes problems, you can instantly switch back to the old version.
"During Updates" means: The time from when you click "update" until the new version is completely ready and working properly.

7.title: Make Things Fast
7.content:
- Programs should start faster than microwaving popcorn (under 2 seconds)
- Buttons should respond instantly when clicked (under 0.1 seconds)
- Don't use too much computer memory - like not hogging all the closet space

8.title: Be Honest About AI Decisions
8.content:
When AI suggests something, it should say:
- "I'm 85% sure this is right" (confidence level)
- "I'm suggesting this because..." (explanation)
- "This was AI version 2.3" (which brain version made the decision)
Where this information is stored:
1. Your computer - Private notes about your work
2. Your company's private storage - Team review notes
3. Our cloud (anonymous only) - Just patterns like "suggestion X was 85% confident" - no actual code or personal info

9.title: Check Your Data
9.content: Make sure the AI's training data is like a fair test - balanced questions, up-to-date information, and correct answers.

10.title: Keep AI Safe
10.content: AI should only work in a special "playground" (sandbox) away from real computers. It can look at code and make suggestions, but never actually run code on people's machines.

11.title: Learn from Mistakes
11.content: When the AI gets something wrong, it should remember that mistake and get smarter, just like you learn from getting test questions wrong.

12.title: Test Everything
12.content: Always try things out before saying they work. Don't break things that already work. Test both simple cases and tricky situations.

13.title: Write Good Instructions
13.content: Give people working examples they can try themselves, clear explanations of how to use things, and troubleshooting guides for when things go wrong.

14.title: Keep Good Logs
14.content: Write clear notes that are easy to read, use special tracking numbers to follow requests through the system, and measure both technical numbers and business results.

15.title: Make Changes Easy to Undo
15.content: Prefer adding new features rather than changing old ones. Use on/off switches for features. Write down how to go back if something doesn't work.

16.title: Make Things Repeatable
16.content: Write down exactly what ingredients (versions) you used. Don't depend on special kitchen equipment (computer setups). Include simple steps so others can recreate your work.

17.title: Keep Different Parts Separate
17.content: The display screen (user interface) only shows information. The thinking part (business logic) only does calculations. Never mix these two jobs.

18.title: Be Fair to Everyone
18.content:
Use clear, simple language everyone can understand. Don't use tricky designs that might confuse people. Make sure people with disabilities can use everything.

19.content:
Our system has four parts:

- Edge Agent ‚Üí Processes data locally for privacy (like thinking in your head)
- Client Cloud ‚Üí Stores company's private data (like a company safe)

20.title: Make All 18 Modules Look the Same
20.content: All 18 tools should use the same buttons, menus, and look. Like different rooms in the same house - they have the same light switches and door handles.

21.title: Process Data Locally First
21.content:
- Source code ‚Üí Never leaves the company (like secret recipes)
- Development data ‚Üí Stays in company cloud (like work notes)
- Anonymous patterns ‚Üí Can go to our cloud (like "people prefer chocolate over vanilla" - no specific info)

22.title: Don't Make People Configure Before Using
22.content: Things should work right out of the box. Like a new video game - you can start playing immediately, and only set up complex controls later if you want.

23.title: Show Information Gradually
23.content:
- Level 1 ‚Üí Basic status (like a traffic light - red/yellow/green)
- Level 2 ‚Üí Suggestions when relevant (like a friend saying "try this")
- Level 3 ‚Üí Full tools when asked (like opening a complete toolbox)

25.title: Be Smart About Data
25.content:

- Company cloud only ‚Üí Team metrics, security scans (like company reports)

26.title: Work Without Internet
26.content: Core features must work offline, like being able to write in a notebook when you don't have WiFi. Save actions and sync when you're back online.

27.title: Register Modules the Same Way
27.content: All 18 modules should sign up using the same process, like every student using the same enrollment form.

28.title: Make All Modules Feel Like One Product
28.content: Use the same command names everywhere, make status indicators look the same, handle errors the same way - like different apps made by the same company.

29.title: Design for Quick Adoption
29.content:
- People should get value in first 30 seconds (like instant fun in a game)
- 80% of users should use each module (like most students using the library)
- 90% should still be using after 30 days (like people sticking with a good habit)

30.title: Test User Experience
30.content:
- No setup needed before use (like instant-on TV)
- First interaction in under 30 seconds (like quick-start instructions)
- System almost never crashes (like reliable car)
- Buttons respond instantly (like light switches)

31.title: Solve Real Developer Problems
31.content: Every feature must fix a real frustration developers face, like making homework easier by having better tools.

32.title: Help People Work Better
32.content:
- Mirror ‚Üí Show people what they're doing now (like a mirror)
- Mentor ‚Üí Guide them to better ways (like a coach)
- Multiplier ‚Üí Help them do more of what works (like a turbo boost)

33.title: Prevent Problems Before They Happen
33.content: Stop issues before they become big problems, like fixing a small leak before it floods the house.

34.title: Be Extra Careful with Private Data
34.content:
- Never look at ‚Üí Production passwords, user personal data (like bank codes)
- Process locally ‚Üí Code analysis, performance checks (like thinking privately)
- Share only ‚Üí Anonymous patterns, general insights (like "students learn better with examples")

35.title: Don't Make People Think Too Hard
35.content: Fix common issues with one click, give suggestions without interrupting, automate boring tasks, teach as you go - like having a helpful friend.

36.title: MMM Engine - Change Behavior
36.content: Help people stop making the same mistakes, increase use of best practices, reduce need for manual fixes, help people solve problems themselves - like a good habit coach.

37.title: Detection Engine - Be Accurate
37.content:
- Wrong alerts ‚Üí Less than 2% for critical issues (like rarely crying wolf)
- Missed problems ‚Üí Less than 1% for security (like rarely missing real danger)
- Show confidence levels clearly (like saying "I'm very sure" or "I'm guessing")
- Learn from corrections (like learning from mistakes)

38.title: Risk Modules - Safety First
38.content: Never make situations worse, always provide undo options, support gradual improvements, verify before big changes - like safety rules in science lab.

39.title: Success Dashboards - Show Business Value
39.content:
Connect engineering work to company results, show money saved and time gained, track both current and future benefits - like showing how studying leads to better grades.

41.title: Process Data Quickly
41.content: Handle urgent data in less than 1 second (like answering important texts immediately), group less important data (like checking regular mail once a day), check data quality as it comes in.

42.title: Help Without Interrupting
42.content: Give help when needed, not before (like waiting to be asked), match help to how complex the task is (like simple vs complex instructions), let experts turn off basic help.

43.title: Handle Emergencies Well
43.content: Make the right action obvious (like big red stop button), provide one-click solutions, offer multiple ways to recover, show clear progress updates - like good emergency instructions.

44.title: Make Developers Happier
44.content: Reduce time spent switching between tasks, cut down on boring repetitive work, increase time spent on meaningful coding, build confidence in deployments - like making schoolwork more enjoyable.

45.title: Track Problems You Prevent
45.content: Count security issues caught early, track deployment failures avoided, measure knowledge gaps found and fixed, watch technical debt prevented - like counting accidents that didn't happen because of safety measures.

46.title: Build Compliance into Workflow
46.content: Check rules automatically during development, monitor compliance in real-time, generate audit reports easily, assess impact of rule changes - like having built-in spell check while writing.

47.title: Security Should Help, Not Block
47.content: Security tips shouldn't break concentration, automate common security fixes, explain security rules in simple terms, prioritize security risks by importance - like friendly security guards rather than prison guards.

48.title: Support Gradual Adoption
48.content: Let teams start with 3-5 most useful modules, each module should work well on its own, show clear paths to add more modules, provide value at every step - like learning math starting with addition, then multiplication.

49.title: Scale from Small to Huge
49.content:
Work for 1 developer or 10,000, handle 100 events per day or 10 million, support simple systems and complex ones, meet basic needs and strict regulations - like a playground that works for both small kids and professional athletes.

50.title: Build for Real Team Work
50.content: Make collaboration natural and easy, help teams share knowledge automatically, reduce meetings and emails through better tools, make it easy to help each other without interrupting work - like good group project tools.

51.title: Prevent Knowledge Silos
51.content: Automatically identify who knows what, suggest when to share important information, help teams learn from each other's successes, make expertise easy to find when needed - like knowing which friend to ask for help with different subjects.

52.title: Reduce Frustration Daily
52.content: Fix the small annoyances that add up, automate boring repetitive tasks, make hard things easier, celebrate small wins and progress - like making daily chores less annoying.

53.title: Build Confidence, Not Fear
53.content: Make deployments feel safe and controlled, provide safety nets for mistakes, show progress and improvements clearly, help people learn without embarrassment - like training wheels on a bike.

54.title: Learn and Adapt Constantly
54.content: Watch how people actually use the product, learn from what works and what doesn't, make the product smarter over time, adapt to different team styles and needs - like a teacher who adjusts to how students learn best.

55.title: Measure What Matters
55.content: Track real improvements, not just activity, measure time saved and stress reduced, watch for positive behavior changes, count problems prevented, not just fixed - like measuring learning, not just time spent studying.

56.title: Catch Issues Early
56.content: Find problems when they're small and easy to fix, warn about potential issues before they happen, suggest simple fixes for common mistakes, prevent small issues from becoming big problems - like fixing a small leak before it becomes a flood.

57.title: Build Safety Into Everything
57.content: Always have an "undo" button, make dangerous actions hard to do accidentally, provide multiple ways to recover from mistakes, test changes safely before applying them - like safety features in cars.

58.title: Automate Wisely
58.content: Only automate things that are boring or error-prone, always let people review and approve important changes, make automation helpful, not annoying, explain what the automation is doing and why - like a helpful robot assistant.

59.title: Learn from Experts
59.content: Watch how the best developers work, copy their successful patterns, help everyone work like the experts, share best practices across the whole team - like learning sports from professional athletes.

60.title: Show the Right Information at the Right Time
60.content: Don't overwhelm people with too much information, show what's important right now, hide complexity until it's needed, make status and progress clear at a glance - like a good car dashboard.

61.title: Make Dependencies Visible
61.content: Show how different pieces connect and depend on each other, warn when changes might affect other people, help teams coordinate without meetings, make the system's architecture easy to understand - like a map showing how roads connect.

62.title: Be Predictable and Consistent
62.content: Work the same way every time, don't surprise people with unexpected behavior, explain clearly what will happen before it happens, build trust through reliability - like a reliable friend.

63.title: Never Lose People's Work
63.content: Save work automatically and frequently, provide clear recovery options, back up important information, warn before doing anything that can't be undone - like automatic save in video games.

64.title: Make it Beautiful and Pleasant
64.content: Use clean, attractive designs, choose pleasant colors and fonts, make interactions smooth and satisfying, create an experience people enjoy using - like a well-designed park.

65.title: Respect People's Time
65.content: Load quickly and respond instantly, don't make people wait unnecessarily, streamline common tasks, value every second of people's time - like express checkout lines.

66.title: Write Clean, Readable Code
66.content: Make code easy to understand and modify, use clear names and simple structures, document why decisions were made, keep code organized and consistent - like writing clear, neat notes.

67.title: Handle Edge Cases Gracefully
67.content: Plan for things going wrong, handle errors without crashing, provide helpful error messages, recover smoothly from problems - like having a plan B when things don't go as expected.

68.title: Encourage Better Ways of Working
68.content: Suggest improvements to processes, help teams adopt better practices, make good habits easy to form, reward continuous improvement - like a good coach.

69.title: Adapt to Different Skill Levels
69.content: Help beginners learn quickly, support experts with advanced features, don't force one way of working on everyone, grow with people as they learn and improve - like books with different reading levels.

70.title: Be Helpful, Not Annoying
70.content: Offer help when it's actually needed, know when to be quiet and stay out of the way, learn what kind of help each person prefers, get better at helping over time - like a helpful friend who knows when to help and when to let you figure things out.

71.title: Explain AI Decisions Clearly
71.content: Don't be a "black box" - show your reasoning, help people understand why you're making suggestions, be honest about uncertainty and limitations, build trust through transparency - like showing your math work instead of just the answer.

72.title: Demonstrate Clear Value
72.content: Show how the product saves time and money, make benefits obvious and measurable, connect features to real business outcomes, prove your worth every day - like showing how studying leads to better grades.

73.title: Grow with the Customer
73.content: Work well for small teams and huge organizations, adapt to different industries and needs, support both simple and complex situations, scale smoothly as needs grow - like clothes that can expand as you grow.

74.title: Create "Magic Moments"
74.content: Occasionally surprise and delight users, make some tasks feel effortless and magical, exceed expectations in small, meaningful ways, create features that people love to show others - like finding an extra french fry at the bottom of the bag.

75.title: Remove Friction Everywhere
75.content: Eliminate unnecessary steps and clicks, simplify complex processes, make common tasks fast and easy, smooth out rough edges in the experience - like making doors automatic so you don't have to push them.

76.title: Roles & Scope
76.content:
- **Author:** writes the change, fills PR template, runs self‚Äëchecks.
- **Reviewer:** verifies intent, risks, tests, and policy compliance. Gives clear, kind feedback.
- **Gatekeeper (CI):** blocks merges on rule violations.
- **AI Assistant (Cursor):** may propose diffs; must follow this Constitution and stop on rule errors.
**Scope & Size Limits**
- **AI code‚Äëgen task limit:** ‚â§ **50 LOC** changed unless the prompt includes `LOC_OVERRIDE:<number>`.
- **PR size guidance:** ‚â§ **300 LOC** changed (tests excluded). If larger, split or include a **Rollout Plan**.
- Sensitive areas (auth, policy, contracts, receipts, migrations) require **CODEOWNERS** approval and may need **two reviewers** (see ¬ß9).
SLA: Reviews should start within **2 business days**.

77.title: Golden Rules (non‚Äënegotiable)
77.content:
1) **Why first.** The PR must state **What changed** and **Why we did it** (problem, constraints, trade‚Äëoffs).
2) **Small, coherent diffs.** One intent per PR; feature‚Äëflags for risky changes.
3) **Tests prove behavior.** No code change without tests that **fail before** and **pass after** the change (or receipts proving behavior for non-code config).
4) **Simple English comments.** Follow the Comments Constitution at file/imports/function/variable/logic levels.
5) **Security & privacy first.** No secrets/PII in code, comments, logs, tests, or fixtures.
6) **Reversible.** Include a rollback/disable plan for non‚Äëtrivial changes (flags or revert steps).

78.title: Review Outcomes & Severity
78.content:
- **Approve** ‚Äî meets all checks; minor nits optional.
- **Request changes** ‚Äî must fix blockers/majors.
- **Comment** ‚Äî non‚Äëblocking feedback or ideas.
Severity levels the reviewer must tag:
- **Blocker:** merge must **not** proceed (critical gaps).
- **Major:** must fix before merge (important, not existential).
- **Minor:** should fix soon or follow‚Äëup issue.
- **Nit:** style/wording; optional.

81.content:

- **Receipts** for significant actions (append‚Äëonly JSONL).

83.title: Automation (CI/Pre‚Äëcommit)
83.content:
- **Lint & format:** ruff/black (Python), eslint/biome (TS).
- **Contracts:** diff and validate OpenAPI/Schema JSON; fail on breaking changes; require contract publish receipt where applicable.
- **Comments:** check for file headers, function docs, PLAN blocks (regex/rules) ‚Äî enforce Comments Constitution stop codes.
- **Logging:** validate sample log lines against `docs/log_schema_v1.json`; fail on missing fields/oversize; enforce request.start/end.
- **Security:** secret scanners; dependency audit with **license allowlist** and **CVE threshold** gate.
- **Storage:** forbid blobs in DB; require DB metadata rows for file writes (static checks where possible).
- **Tests:** require new/changed paths covered; run unit/integration; collect perf receipts for hot paths.
- **Governance:** require **CODEOWNERS** approval for sensitive paths and **two reviewers** (owner + guild) where mandated.
- **Receipts:** ensure `receipt.emit` present for privileged/business‚Äëcritical actions.

84.title: Review Comment Style (simple English)
84.content:
- Be kind. Focus on the code, not the person.
- Explain **why** you suggest a change. Use short sentences.
- Offer a **concrete diff** when possible.
- Mark severity: **Blocker/Major/Minor/Nit**.
- Ask clarifying questions; avoid sarcasm or jargon.
**Examples**  
- *Blocker:* ‚ÄúIdempotency not enforced on retry; please add idempotencyKey and conflict handling.‚Äù  
- *Major:* ‚ÄúAPI response adds a field without version bump; please update OpenAPI and mark as non‚Äëbreaking.‚Äù  
- *Minor:* ‚ÄúComment uses jargon (‚Äòinstantiate‚Äô). Please rewrite in simple English.‚Äù  
- *Nit:* ‚ÄúConsider renaming var to match style: `maxBatch` ‚Üí `MAX_BATCH`.‚Äù

85.title: Return Contracts (review output)
85.content:
- **Approve:** brief summary + any minor nits.
- **Request changes:** list blockers/majors with bullet points and suggested fix.
- **Comment:** ideas or questions; no merge block.

86.title: PYTHON (FastAPI) QUALITY GATES
86.content:
- Tools: ruff + black (line length 100) + mypy --strict.
- Runtime: Python 3.11+. Use Pydantic v2 models; never return raw ORM.
- FastAPI: every route has response_model; validate inputs; error envelope only (no plain strings).
- Async only for handlers; avoid blocking calls; httpx for async tests.
- Packaging: pip-tools lock with hashes; no unpinned deps.

87.title: TYPESCRIPT QUALITY GATES
87.content:
- tsconfig: "strict": true, "noImplicitAny": true, "exactOptionalPropertyTypes": true, ES2022+, ESNext modules.
- eslint + prettier required; no `any` in committed code.
- API types are generated from OpenAPI; do not hand-roll DTOs for server contracts.

88.title: API CONTRACTS (HTTP)
88.content:
- OpenAPI 3.1 is the source of truth; URI versioning /v1, /v2...
- Mutations MUST accept Idempotency-Key; lists are cursor-paginated; standard headers include X-API-Version and X-Request-Id.
- Stable error envelope with canonical codes; no 200-with-error patterns.
- Changes that are breaking require a new major version and deprecation process.

89.title: DATABASE (PostgreSQL primary; SQLite for dev/test)
89.content:
- SQLAlchemy 2.x; explicit columns (no SELECT *); name constraints/indexes.
- Schema changes ONLY via Alembic; additive-first; include safe DOWN migration.
- SQLite (dev/test) uses WAL + busy_timeout=5000; mirror Postgres schema.

90.title: SECURITY & SECRETS
90.content:
- No secrets in code, tests, examples, logs, or repo. Use env + OS keyring/DPAPI. Provide .env.template only.
- Validate inputs; set security headers; CORS allowlist only (no * in prod).
- Run dependency & secret scans; block known CVEs.

91.title: OBSERVABILITY & RECEIPTS
91.content:
- Logs are structured JSON: timestamp, level, service, route, httpStatus, latencyMs, traceId/spanId, apiVersion.
- Emit JSONL receipts for privileged actions (planned/success/aborted/error) with ts_utc, monotonic_hw_time_ms, traceId, policy_snapshot_hash.

92.title: TESTING PROGRAM
92.content:
- Tests first; pytest (‚â•90% where applicable) + httpx for API; property tests with hypothesis where valuable.
- DB tests transactional with rollback; CI must run unit + integration tests; coverage must not drop.

93.title: LLM / OLLAMA
93.content:
- Use pinned llama3 variant with deterministic params (low temperature, fixed seed); enforce token/time budgets.
- Redact PII/secrets before inference; never log raw prompts with secrets.
- For codegen, output ONLY the specified Return Contract format (see ¬ß12).

94.title: SUPPLY CHAIN & RELEASE INTEGRITY
94.content:
- Signed commits/tags; SBOMs attached; pinned lockfiles (pip-tools with hashes, npm ci).
- Container bases pinned by digest; non-root; read-only FS where possible.

95.title: PERFORMANCE & RELIABILITY
95.content: - Publish per-route SLOs (p95) in policy; add timeouts, retries (idempotent), backpressure; avoid event-loop blocking.

96.title: DOCS & RUNBOOKS
96.content: - Accurate OpenAPI; examples for all responses; ADRs for architectural changes; runbooks for migrations/rollbacks.

132.title: LOG FORMAT & TRANSPORT
132.content:

- Ask the LLM: ‚ÄúBuild a timeline of the failure. Show the causal chain using event_id/caused_by/links. Rank root cause candidates.‚Äù
# ZeroUI 2.0 Exception Handling Rules (Enhanced)
üéØ **Purpose:** Keep apps stable, users calm, and debugging easy‚Äîby turning messy errors into a few clear, friendly outcomes.

150.title: Prevent First
150.content: Validate inputs early (required, type, range, size). Prevention beats cure.

151.title: Small, Stable Error Codes
151.content:
Adopt ~10‚Äì12 canonical codes with severity levels:
- `HIGH`: DEPENDENCY_FAILED, UNEXPECTED_ERROR, TIMEOUT
- `MEDIUM`: RATE_LIMITED, CONFLICT, INVARIANT_VIOLATION  
- `LOW`: VALIDATION_ERROR, NOT_FOUND, PERMISSION_DENIED, CANCELLED

152.title: Wrap & Chain
152.content: When a low-level error occurs, wrap it into your code with a friendly message and keep the original as the cause. Never throw raw framework/driver errors at the edges.

153.title: Central Handler at Boundaries
153.content:
Have one handler per surface (API endpoint, CLI entry, IDE command) that:
- maps codes ‚Üí friendly messages
- sets the right status/exit code  
- logs details (with cause chain)

154.title: Friendly to Users, Detailed in Logs
154.content: Users see short, calm guidance. Logs contain context and the cause chain. Never leak secrets.

155.title: No Silent Catches
155.content: Never swallow errors. If you catch it, either fix, retry (if safe), or wrap & bubble to the central handler.

156.title: Add Context
156.content: Always include where/what (operation name, ids, step) when wrapping. This speeds up root-cause analysis.

157.title: Cleanup Always
157.content: Close files, sockets, timers; release locks. Use "always-run" cleanup paths. Avoid resource leaks.

158.title: Error Recovery Patterns
158.content:
Define clear recovery actions for each error type:
- After `CANCELLED`: Reset operation state
- After `DEPENDENCY_FAILED`: Show fallback content or retry later
- After `VALIDATION_ERROR`: Guide user to correct input
- Document when to show "Try Again" vs. "Contact Support"

159.title: New Developer Onboarding
159.content:
- Provide "First Error Handling Task" template
- Include examples of proper wrapping patterns  
- Document the "why" behind each major rule
- Pair new developers with error handling experts

160.title: Timeouts Everywhere
160.content: All I/O (network, file, DB, subprocess) must have a timeout (configurable). No infinite waits.

161.title: Limited Retries with Backoff
161.content: Retry only idempotent operations. Max 2‚Äì3 tries. Use exponential backoff + small jitter.

162.title: Do Not Retry Non-Retriables
162.content: No retries for validation errors, 401/403, 404, or business rule failures. Surface the issue; guide the user.

163.title: Idempotency
163.content: Design writes so they are safe to retry (keys/tokens/conflict handling). Document this in your service contract.

164.title: HTTP/Exit Mapping
164.content: Map canonical codes to standard outcomes (e.g., 400/401/403/404/409/422/429/5xx). No "200 with error body".

165.title: Message Catalog
165.content: Keep a single catalog that maps each code ‚Üí one friendly, human sentence. Translate here, not in code.

166.title: UI/IDE Behavior
166.content: Keep UI responsive. Show short, actionable options: Retry / Cancel / Open Logs. No stack traces to users.

167.title: Structured Logs
167.content: One JSON object per line. Include: timestamp, level, service, operation, error.code, trace/request ids, duration, attempt, retryable flag, severity, and a cause chain summary.

168.title: Correlation
168.content: Propagate trace/request ids across calls. Log exactly one request.start and one request.end per request.

169.title: Privacy & Secrets
169.content: Never log secrets or PII. Redact tokens, passwords, cookies, Authorization headers, and sensitive payloads. Log sizes/hashes, not raw bodies.

170.title: Test Failure Paths
170.content:
Write tests for:
- Happy path
- Timeouts and 5xx errors  
- 4xx errors (validation/permission)
- Dependency failures
- Cleanup execution verification
- Error cause chain preservation
- Recovery behavior after errors

171.title: Contracts & Docs
171.content: Document the error envelope, code list, HTTP mapping, and examples. Keep examples up to date and non-PII.

172.title: Consistency Over Cleverness
172.content: Prefer consistent handling over one-off fixes. If a new case appears, map it to an existing code first.

173.title: Safe Defaults
173.content: Default timeouts, retry caps, and user messages must be safe and configurable. No hidden magic numbers.

174.title: AI Decision Transparency
174.content:
When AI suggests something, include:
- Confidence level (e.g., "I'm 85% sure this is right")
- Reasoning explanation ("I'm suggesting this because...")
- AI version information ("This was AI version 2.3")

175.title: AI Sandbox Safety
175.content: AI should only work in a special "playground" (sandbox) away from real computers. It can look at code and make suggestions, but never actually run code on people's machines.

176.title: AI Learning from Mistakes
176.content: When the AI gets something wrong, it should remember that mistake and get smarter, just like learning from test questions.

177.title: AI Confidence Thresholds
177.content:
- High confidence (>90%): Apply automatically with user notification
- Medium confidence (70-90%): Suggest with explanation
- Low confidence (<70%): Ask for explicit user approval

178.title: Graceful Degradation
178.content: When dependencies fail, provide reduced functionality rather than complete failure. Show clear status of what's working vs. limited.

179.title: State Recovery
179.content: After crashes or failures, systems should recover to known good states. Maintain recovery checkpoints for long-running operations.

180.title: Feature Flag Safety
180.content: Use feature flags for risky changes with automatic rollback on error detection. Monitor error rates by flag state.

181.title: Strict Mode Always
181.content: Turn on strict checks everywhere. (Meaning: the compiler catches more mistakes early.)

182.title: No `any` in committed code
182.content: If you don't know the type, use **`unknown`** and **check it** before use.

183.title: Handle `null`/`undefined`
183.content: Use optional fields only when needed, and **check** before using values.

184.title: Small, Clear Functions
184.content: Short functions, clear names. One job per function.

185.title: Consistent Naming
185.content:
* files: kebab-case.ts
* variables/functions: camelCase
* types/interfaces/enums: PascalCase
* constants: UPPER_SNAKE_CASE

186.title: Clear Shape Strategy
186.content: Use **`interface`** for object shapes you'll extend, **`type`** for unions and utilities. Stay consistent across the repo.

187.title: Let the Compiler Infer
187.content: Don't add types the compiler already knows. (Meaning: avoid noisy annotations.)

188.title: Keep Imports Clean
188.content: No unused imports. Group by built-in, third-party, then local.

189.title: Describe the Shape
189.content: Make simple named types for real data (User, Order). Reuse them.

190.title: Union & Narrowing
190.content: If something can be **A or B**, say so. **Check which one** before using it.

191.title: Readonly by Default
191.content: Prefer readonly arrays/props for values that should not change.

192.title: Discriminated Unions
192.content: When you have variants, add a simple **kind** field and switch on it. (Meaning: safer branching.)

194.title: Generics, But Simple
194.content: Use generics when it truly makes code reusable. Keep names short and clear.

195.title: No Unhandled Promises
195.content: Always `await` or handle `.catch`. Never let a promise fail silently.

196.title: Timeouts & Cancel
196.content: Use timeouts for network/work that may hang. Support **AbortController** for cancellable operations.

197.title: Friendly Errors at Edges
197.content: Catch errors at boundaries (commands, routes) and show **short, calm messages**. Put details in logs (no secrets).

198.title: Map Errors to Codes
198.content: Convert messy errors into a **small set** of stable codes (e.g., VALIDATION, NOT_FOUND, TIMEOUT, DEPENDENCY_FAILED, UNEXPECTED). Be consistent.

199.title: Retries Are Limited
199.content: Retry only **safe** (idempotent) actions, at most 2‚Äì3 times, with backoff. Never retry validation or permission errors.

200.title: One Source of Truth
200.content: Keep types for APIs in one place (e.g., generated from contracts). Don't hand-roll duplicates.

201.title: Folder Layout
201.content: Group by **feature**, then by file type (types, logic, tests). Avoid deep "barrel" re-exports chains.

202.title: Paths & Aliases
202.content: Use path aliases in config (short imports), but **don't** create cycles.

203.title: Modern Output Targets
203.content: Target modern JS (ES2022+) for optimal tree-shaking. Keep configs in repo. Builds must be reproducible.

204.title: Lint & Format
204.content: Use eslint + prettier. No warnings in CI.

205.title: Type Check in CI
205.content: Run the compiler (`tsc`) with strict settings on every PR.

206.title: Tests for New Behavior
206.content: Add tests for new logic and for error paths (timeouts, bad input). Keep tests fast.

207.title: Comments in Simple English
207.content: Explain **what** and **why** in short sentences. Avoid jargon.

208.title: No Secrets in Code or Logs
208.content: Never commit tokens/passwords. Redact sensitive values from logs.

209.title: Validate Untrusted Inputs at Runtime
209.content: Types help at build time only. Validate external data before use.

210.title: Keep the UI Responsive
210.content: Do heavy work off the main thread. Show progress for long tasks.

211.title: Review AI Code Thoroughly
211.content: All AI-generated TypeScript must be reviewed by humans. Verify types, error handling, and security match our standards.

212.title: Monitor Bundle Impact
212.content: Use path imports for large libraries. Avoid barrel imports in hot paths. Set bundle size budgets and monitor them.

213.title: Quality Dependencies
213.content: Prefer packages with built-in TypeScript definitions. Use `@types/` packages from DefinitelyTyped. Audit dependencies for type safety.

214.title: Test Type Boundaries
214.content: Write tests that verify type narrowing works. Test error cases to ensure proper typing. Use `@ts-expect-error` for expected type failures.

215.title: Gradual Migration Strategy
215.content: When converting JavaScript to TypeScript, use `// @ts-check` in JS files first. Add JSDoc types before conversion. Convert one module at a time.

216.title: READABILITY STANDARD (R008)
216.content:
- Short sentences (‚â§ 20 words). Common words. Avoid jargon and passive voice.
- If a hard word is needed, add "meaning: <plain words>".
- Use bullets for steps. Explain decisions and trade‚Äëoffs, not line‚Äëby‚Äëline code.
- **Measurable Criteria**: Flesch-Kincaid Grade Level ‚â§ 8.0, Average Sentence Length ‚â§ 15 words
- **Auto-Detection**: Comments with complex words (‚â•3 syllables) or passive voice trigger warnings
- **Examples**:
  ‚úì "Check if user is logged in" (Grade 3.2)
  ‚úó "Verify authentication status of the current user session" (Grade 8.7)

217.title: WHERE COMMENTS MUST APPEAR
217.content:
A) File‚Äëlevel header (top of every file) ‚Äî in simple English:
   What, Why, Reads/Writes (paths/tables/receipts), Contracts/Policy IDs, Risks.
B) Imports‚Äëlevel (top import block) ‚Äî group stdlib / third‚Äëparty / local and say **why** each group exists.
C) Function/Class‚Äëlevel (public APIs) ‚Äî WHAT + WHY + Steps + Inputs/Outputs (special rules only) + Fails/Throws + Security/Privacy note.
D) Variable‚Äëlevel (non‚Äëobvious values/constants) ‚Äî meaning, units, allowed range, and reason.
E) Logic‚Äëlevel (before tricky if/loops) ‚Äî a short PLAN/RATIONALE in bullets.

218.title: FILE‚ÄëTYPE FOCUS (add these in headers or near the write)
218.content:
- config: explain each setting; safe defaults; allowed range.
- service: plain business rule; which API/DB it touches.
- log: what we log and why; redaction rules; include traceId.
- receipt: what decision is recorded; include ts_utc, monotonic_hw_time_ms, action, result, traceId, policy_snapshot_hash.
- db (migration): why now; online‚Äësafe plan (additive first, concurrent index); rollback; cutover flag.
- blob: format; size limits; storage path; privacy (redaction/encryption if any).
- backup: schedule; retention; restore test plan.
- audit: append‚Äëonly rule; who writes; integrity check (hash/signature).

219.title: Name Casing & Charset (Kebab-Case Only)
219.content: All folder names must use kebab-case: only lowercase letters, numbers, and hyphens [a-z0-9-]. No uppercase, no underscores, no spaces. This ensures consistency and avoids path resolution issues across platforms.

220.title: No Source Code/PII in Stores
220.content: Storage must never contain source code or personally identifiable information (PII). Use handles, IDs, and metadata only. Receipts and evidence stores are for facts about work, not the work itself.

221.title: No Secrets/Private Keys on Disk
221.content: Never store secrets, passwords, API keys, or private keys on disk. Use secrets manager, HSM, or KMS. Only public keys may be stored in `trust/pubkeys/`. Load sensitive configuration from environment variables or secure vaults.

222.title: JSONL Receipts (Newline-Delimited, Signed, Append-Only)
222.content: Receipts are the legal truth. Format: newline-delimited JSON (JSONL), one record per line. Each line must be signed over canonical JSON. Receipts are append-only‚Äînever modify or delete existing entries. Invalid lines go to quarantine (laptop) or DLQ (cloud).

223.title: Time Partitions Use UTC (dt=YYYY-MM-DD)
223.content: All time-based partitions must use UTC format: `dt=YYYY-MM-DD` (zero-padded). Example: `dt=2025-10-20`. Never use local time, YYYYMMDD format, or MM-DD-YYYY. Optional hot sharding: `dt=.../shard={00..ff}/`.

224.title: Policy Snapshots Must Be Signed
224.content: All policy snapshots and templates must be signed. Laptops cache policies; authoritative publishing happens in the Product plane. Policy files are JSON and signed for integrity verification.

225.title: Dual Storage Compliance (JSONL Authority, DB Mirrors)
225.content: JSONL is the authority. Databases (SQLite/Postgres) mirror data for read/query performance, storing raw JSON verbatim with minimal indexes. The database is a read/index plane only. Always write to JSONL first, then mirror to DB.

226.title: Path Resolution via ZU_ROOT Environment Variable
226.content: All storage paths must be resolved via `ZU_ROOT` environment variable or `config/paths.json`. Never hardcode absolute paths like `D:\ZeroUI` or `/home/user/zeroui`. Enables portable, configurable deployments.

227.title: Receipts Validation (Signed, Append-Only, No Code/PII)
227.content: When reading receipts, always verify signatures. Receipts must never contain source code or PII‚Äîonly handles, IDs, and metadata. Enforce append-only semantics: use file mode "a", never "w"; never truncate or seek.

228.title: Evidence Watermarks Per-Consumer Structure
228.content: Evidence watermarks must follow per-consumer structure: `.../evidence/watermarks/{consumer-id}/`. Each consumer (metrics, traces, logs, etc.) has its own watermark directory for tracking processing progress.

229.title: RFC Fallback Pattern (UNCLASSIFIED__slug, 24h Resolution)
229.content:
When data classification is ambiguous, use RFC fallback: `UNCLASSIFIED__<slug>` (kebab-case slug). Place in:
- IDE: `agent/tmp/UNCLASSIFIED__<slug>`
- Tenant/Product: `ingest/staging/unclassified/<slug>`
Resolve within 24 hours via RFC process, then move to canonical location with proper manifests and checksums.

230.title: Observability/Adapters Use dt= Partitions
230.content:
Observability and adapter paths require date partitions (`dt=YYYY-MM-DD`):
- `observability/(metrics|traces|logs)/dt=YYYY-MM-DD/`
- `adapters/(webhooks|gateway-logs)/dt=YYYY-MM-DD/`
- `reporting/marts/dt=YYYY-MM-DD/`
- `service-metrics/(metrics|traces|logs)/dt=YYYY-MM-DD/`

231.title: Laptop Receipts Use YYYY/MM Partitioning
231.content: Laptop (IDE) receipts use month partitioning: `ide/agent/receipts/{repo-id}/{YYYY}/{MM}/`. Example: `ide/agent/receipts/zeroui2-0/2025/10/`. Auxiliary folders (index, quarantine, checkpoints) live under the same repo path.
